awd_titl_txt: Development of Quaternary Diamond-like Semiconductors for Infrared Nonlinear Optical Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Nonlinear optical (NLO) crystals are used to shift the coherent, monochromatic light of lasers to other desirable wavelengths. Infrared nonlinear optical applications include, stand-off detection of drugs and explosives, non-invasive medical diagnosis and monitoring by breath analysis using molecular spectroscopy and infrared counter-measure systems used to defend military aircraft, just to name a few. However, the current commercially available crystals for use in infrared nonlinear optical devices suffer from drawbacks and are lacking in critical areas that limit their practical applications. The discovery of new infrared nonlinear optical materials enables the realization of new applications impacting medical, industrial and military sectors. Furthermore, the synthesis of improved infrared nonlinear optical materials allows for more reliable, longer-lasting devices having greater impact in areas where these materials have already found utility. Better understanding the relationship between the structure of the crystal and its resulting properties allows for faster progress in this field. Through this project, structure-property correlations are evolving from systematic studies of quaternary diamond-like semiconductors that combine strategic experimentation with theory, in which the ability to reliably predict properties is fostered by experimental results. These structure-property relationships are being revealed by the research efforts of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, undergraduate researchers, high school science teachers and high school students on the research team. X-ray powder diffraction workshops organized through this project are training the next-generation workforce to solve complex scientific problems with the use of advanced research tools. Outreach activities geared toward women, minorities and economically disadvantaged students are taking place through the research group's participation in the ACS Project SEED program and interactions with local undergraduate women in STEM fields.


Technical Abstract
Current commercially available infrared nonlinear optical crystals have shortcomings, such as a lack of power-handling ability and multiphoton absorption effects that preclude usage with high-powered lasers and operation at certain wavelengths, respectively. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, focuses on the synthesis and characterization of quaternary diamond-like semiconductors and the assessment of their potential as new infrared nonlinear optical materials. Nonlinear optical (NLO) properties on powdered diamond-like semiconductor samples and additional properties of centimeter-sized single crystals are being assessed. The powdered/microcrystalline compound samples are prepared by high-temperature solid-state or lithium polysulfide flux synthesis. Second-order nonlinear optical susceptibility, laser damage threshold and the onset wavelength for phase matchability, as well as transparency range and bandgap are being measured. The preparation of centimeter-scale single crystals of selected compounds identified as promising candidates is being carried out via the vertical Bridgman method and iodine-vapor transport reactions. Certain properties of technological importance, including thermal conductivity and extreme optical transparency measured by laser calorimetry, are being assessed using these sizeable single crystals. Relationships between the composition, crystal structure and electronic structure of the materials, especially bandgap, and the observed physical properties are being considered to build crystal-chemical concepts that allow for knowledge-based optimization of materials' NLO properties.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop quaternary, diamond-like semiconductors (DLSs) for infrared (IR) nonlinear optical (NLO) applications. DLSs are materials having crystal structures that are related to that of diamond with low electrical conductivities at room temperature that increase with increasing temperature. Materials with a diamond-like structure are capable of the NLO phenomenon called second harmonic generation (SHG), where the material can double the frequency of an incoming laser, thus shifting laser light to other more desirable wavelengths for use in various industrial, military and medical applications, where solid-state laser devices are used. 

Intellectual Merit: During this project, the Aitken team discovered forty-four new compounds using the high-temperature, solid-state synthetic method. The crystal structures, i.e. the arrangement of atoms within the solid, of these novel materials were elucidated using high-quality structural studies carried out with various techniques, such as single crystal X-ray diffraction. Physical property measurements were performed on many of the new materials to examine: 1) bandgap, 2) SHG response, and 3) laser-induced damage threshold (LIDT). The bandgap energy, the energy required to promote an electron from the valence band to the conduction band in a semiconductor, dictates the application(s) for which the material will be useful. Bandgaps were determined both experimentally, using spectroscopy, and computationally using fundamental theory. The SHG measurements assess the efficiency at which the NLO material can half the wavelength of the incoming laser. LIDT determination provides the laser intensity under which an NLO material begins to degrade in performance, i.e. suffer optical damage. In general, the goal is to maximize both the SHG response as well as the LIDT; however, these properties are generally inversely related, where materials with wide bandgaps tend to have modest SHG responses but high LIDTs.

Through this project, the Aitken team uncovered several new, wide-bandgap materials, such as  α-Li2ZnGeS4, Li4CdSn2S7 and Li4CdGe2S7 with very attractive sets of properties including strong SHG response and high LIDT. These materials are considered serious contenders for next-generation NLO devices in the infrared region. For example, materials discovered in this project could be used in laser-devices impacting national security, such as infrared counter-measure systems. To take some of the next-generation candidate materials to the next stage, the team carried out crystal growth studies for several compounds including Cu2CdSiS4, Cu2ZnSiS4, and Li2MnGeS4, where the maximum crystal size was increased from millimeters to centimeters.

The Aitken team also made an important contribution to the field by publishing a paper underscoring the importance of reference quality and broadband NLO measurements using the Kurtz-Perry powder technique, which is the most frequently used method for the evaluation of NLO properties of newly discovered materials in polycrystalline form.

Broader Impacts: This project provided a rich educational experience in new materials discovery and crystal growth for many individuals; the research was carried out by one visiting professor from a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI), two postdoctoral fellows, six graduate students, and 14 undergraduate students.

The results of this project have been disseminated in the form of peer-reviewed scientific-journal publications, as well as both oral and poster presentations at local, regional, national and international conferences. The PI gave presentations at three conferences and seminars for three universities. There were two presentations delivered by postdoctoral associates, twenty-six presentations communicated by graduate students, and eight presentations exhibited by undergraduate students at conferences, such as the National American Chemical Society (ACS) meeting, the Gordon Conference in Solid-State Chemistry and the North American Solid-State Chemistry conference. Two of the undergraduate students completed a senior, honors thesis and one additional undergraduate student will complete a senior, honors thesis in the spring of 2023 based on the work carried out in this project. Two graduate student Ph.D. dissertations were completed during this award and several other Ph.D. dissertations will be completed in the near future, based on the research conducted in this project. The team that partook in the project benefited from collaborations with researchers from two companies and twenty-one academic institutions, including four PUIs, from across the country and around the world. One graduate student conducted a semester-long internship at a company and another non-traditional graduate student was able to work in industry while conducting part-time research on this project.

Toward the goal of providing crystallographic education and instrumentation to more students and researchers, the Pittsburgh Practical Powder Diffraction Workshop (3PD) was held in May of 2019. Forty-nine participants, mainly graduate students, enrolled in the workshop. In total, eighteen poster presentations were delivered during the workshop. Additionally, toward this educational objective, X-ray diffraction data were made available to researchers from several nearby PUIs, either through on-site visitations or mailing in of samples.
